question1a.value:
1. Clickbait in headlines is increasing over time 
2. Clickbait increases when news sites introduce ad revenue

question2a.value: No interactions as this is correlational research

question5a.value: The internet has revolutionized the way in which we consume news, and this migration from print to digital has fundamentally reshaped the economic structure of the media industry. Over a quarter of newspaper revenue now comes from digital advertising, with this share growing every year (Pew Research Centre, 2018). This puts pressure on newspapers to increase traffic to their websites in order to maximize revenues: this can be done through use of clickbait. Clickbait is a term used to describe articles and headlines written in a dramatic manner in order to grab users’ attention and get them to click onto and read additional content. The headline is made to seem exciting, but the content of the article may not always deliver on the promise of the headline. Clickbait uses our attention system to generate curiosity and cognitive arousal, causing us to engage more with content. Clickbait headlines results in negative effects on perceived source credibility (Hurst, 2016), and fake news stories with clickbait headlines were viewed 38 million times on Facebook prior to the 2016 US presidential election (Allcott & Gentzkow, 2017). The role of clickbait in the attention economy suggests that newspapers who have incentives to increase ad revenue will increase clickbait, and that clickbait will generally increase over time.

attributes.title: Meta-Analytical Review of factors affecting attitudes to immigration

summary.value: This study summarizes the individual and contextual factors explaining general attitudes to immigration. To do so, I first review quantitative peer-reviewed articles in top 20 political science journals featuring individual attitudes to immigration as the dependent variable. To identify relevant articles, I employ the following inclusion criterion: the articles must be written in English, must be published in one of the top 20 political science journal between the years 2010 - 2019, they must use individual attitudes to immigration as the dependent variable, they must use a quantitative methodology. Using this strategy, I conduct a meta-analysis of the relevant models.

attributes.title: "Truth-WIll-Out"
attributes.description: Testing the conditions under which people believe others will come to share their beliefs over time.

q1.value: Belief in a Favorable Future: Truth Emergence or Optimism?

q3.value: In a recent study, Rogers, Moore, & Norton (2018) provide evidence of what they call “belief in a favorable future” – the belief that, over time, the people around us will come to share our preferences and beliefs. We employ a modified paradigm to disentangle the potential mechanisms behind such a belief. We also present suggestive evidence that the extent to which a person exhibits this tendency about a particular belief can be used as implicit measure of the strength of that belief.

q4.value:
(i) People believe that in the future, as compared to the present, others will share their beliefs to a greater degree (replication of "belief in a favorable future").

(ii) "Belief in a favorable future" even stronger when a person's own belief is objectively correct.

(iii) The desirability of the underlying belief has no effect on the strength of "belief in a favorable future".

(iv) For politically-polarized beliefs, partisans show a weaker "belief in a favorable future" when they believes something congenial to their political alignment, relative to when they believe something poltiically neutral or noncongenial.

(v) People believe others will agree with them in the future more strongly for the rejection of false beliefs as compared to the acceptance of true beliefs. In other words, people believe myths will be dispelled over time more than they believe truth will be accepted.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: No human contact with study participants.

question.value: Observational study in which each subject is asked to provide judgements about 24 different statements. The statements vary on 3 dimensions: truth, desirability, and political polarization.

q9.value: No randomization aside from the order in which the items are presented (counterbalancing)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit 500 subjects from the Amazon Mechanical Turk subject pool through CloudResearch (formerly TurkPrime). Subjects will be eligible if they have a greater than 90% HIT approval rate, are over 18, and reside in the United States. Participants will be paid the equivalent of $6.00 per hour, prorated for the average completion time of the task. The study will be posted and completed in mid-February.

q13.value: We will analyze 24 responses each from 500 subjects, for a total of 12,000 item-level data points.

q14.value: 500 subjects is the largest sample the current research budget allows.

q15.value: All data will be collected in one period with automatic termination at 500 subjects.

question.value: None. Our inventory of 24 beliefs has been pre-tested to establish variation in the following aspects of the item: true/false, desirable/undesirable, political/nonpolitical, and within political items, congenial to Republicans or Democrats.

For each statement, we ask: 
1. Does the participant believe the statement is true? (Yes or No)
2. What is their level of confidence? (0-100 slider)
3. In terms of the American population, what percentage do they think agree with them currently? (0-100 slider)
4. In terms of the American population, what percentage do they think agree with them in five years? (0-100 slider)
5. Whether or not they believe it, would they like to believe it? (5 point Likert scale, endpoints "I very much would not like to believe this statement" and "I would very much like to believe this statement").

We also collect covariates:
1. Age
2. Sex
3. Race
4. Income
5. Level of education
6. Political orientation
7. Political party

(i) People believe that in the future, as compared to the present, others will share their beliefs to a greater degree (replication of "belief in a favorable future").

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between "future agreement" and "current agreement" significantly different from zero?

(ii) "Belief in a favorable future" is even stronger when a person's own belief is objectively correct.

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly different between items on which the participant's assessment of the statement was correct, versus on which they were incorrect?

Linear regression: Is the beta for "correct" different from zero and positive in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "correct" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect

(iii) The desirability of the underlying belief has no effect on the strength of "belief in a favorable future".

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly different between items which were pre-tested to be desirable and items pre-tested to be undesirable?

Linear regression: Is the beta for "desirable" different from zero in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "desirable" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect

(iv) For politically-polarized beliefs, partisans show a weaker "belief in a favorable future" when they believes something congenial to their political alignment, relative to when they believe something politically neutral or noncongenial.

Two-tailed t-test: On items that participants believe to be true, is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly smaller for items which are congenial to their political beliefs than for items that are not congenial?

Linear regression on items participants indicate they believe to be true: Is the beta for "congenial" different from zero and negative in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "congenial" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect (we will run two separate models for Democrats and Republicans).

(v) People believe others will agree with them in the future more strongly for the rejection of false beliefs as compared to the acceptance of true beliefs. In other words, people believe myths will be dispelled over time more than they believe truth will be accepted.

Two-tailed t-test: Is the mean difference between future and current agreement significantly larger for items which participants believe to be false than for items participants believe to be true?

Linear regression: Is the beta for "believe" different from zero and negative in the following specification? Mean diff. in agreement = "believe" + demographic covariates + political orientation + participant fixed effect

q21.value: We will use a p-value of 0.05 as our criterion for statistical significance. We will use two-tailed tests for our analyses.

q22.value: We will use an attention check with directed responses for participants. Participants that fail the check will be excluded from data analysis.

q23.value: Any surveys with missing responses will be excluded in their entirety from the analysis.

q24.value:
-We will confirm that the political items int eh survey actually are viewed differently by partisans of different political orientations.
-We will confirm that our items pre-tested for desirability and undesirability conform with the results of the pre-test.
-We will examine relationships between demographic covariates (including political orientation) and the main outcomes of interest.

attributes.title: The Relationship Between Cognitive and Linguistic Ablilities in Bilingual Children

q1.value: The Relationship Between Cognitive and Linguistic Abilities in Bilingual Children

q2.value: Ines Elena Martin, Sara Incera, Paz Suarez-Coalla

q3.value: The goal of the present investigation is to determine how bilingualism influences reading. To date few studies have addressed this question despite the millions of children who are learning to read in bilingual environments. The grain size accommodation hypothesis (Lallier & Carreiras, 2018) proposes that cross-linguistic variations (the differences between languages) and cross-linguistic transfer (the influence from one language to another) affect bilingual reading strategies as well as cognitive function. Sparks, Ganschow, and Pohlman (1989) proposed the linguistic coding differences hypothesis to further explain the relationship between native and second-language reading difficulties. These authors suggest that children who have difficulty reading in their native language will also show difficulties reading in their second language. The explanation behind this reasoning is that the same skill deficits will be present because both native and second language reading depend on the same set of linguistic skills (Li, Tao, Joshi, & Xu, 2018; Sparks, Ganschow, & Pohlman, 1989). In the present study we will examine the extent to which reading performance is determine by resistance to distractor interference (as measured in the Flanker task) and practice reading (as measured through a self-report questionnaire of number of hours reading in each language). Our study focuses on the relationship between cognitive and linguistic abilities. Our population are 8 to 10 years-old students that are currently attending a Spanish immersion school in the USA. Students will be presented with two tasks: a Flanker task and a Lexical decision task.

q4.value:
(1) Students’ performance in the cognitive task (Flanker) will predict students’ performance in the linguistic task (Lexical Decision). 
1A - If cognitive ability (i.e., resistance to distractor interference) is related to phonological interference in the first language of a bilingual, the Flanker effect (the difference between the congruent and the incongruent conditions in the flanker task) will correlate with the English homophone effect (the difference between the English homophone non-word bloo and the no-rules non-word uebl). 
1B - If cognitive ability (i.e., resistance to distractor interference) is related phonological interference in the second language of a bilingual, the Flanker effect (the difference between the congruent and the incongruent conditions in the flanker task) will correlate with the Spanish homophone effect (the difference between the Spanish homophone non-word blu and the no-rules non-word uebl). 

(2) Students’ educational experiences (e.g., self-reported amount of reading) will predict students’ performance in the linguistic task.
- Number of hours reading will correlate with overall performance across conditions in the lexical decision task.

(3) Within the linguistic task, students’ performance in the English pseudohomophones will predict students’ performance in the Spanish pseudohomophones.
- If there is a mechanism that controls phonological interference across languages, the English homophone effect (the difference between the English homophone non-word bloo and the no-rules non-word uebl) will correlate with the Spanish homophone effect (the difference between the Spanish homophone non-word blu and the no-rules non-word uebl).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Participants in the present investigation will (1) provide consent, (2) complete tasks in the computer, and (3) respond to a series of questions about their linguistic background. The tasks that participants will complete in the computer will be run using the MouseTracker software, a program that records participants’ computer mouse movements. Participants will first complete the Flanker task (a task that measures resistance to distractor interference) where participants need to ignore the surrounding arrows and click on the direction of the arrow in the center. Second participants will complete a lexical decision task, a reading task where participants need to decide whether a particular string of letters is a word or not. Regarding the questionnaire at the end, all children will be asked the questions orally.

q9.value: All trials within each task will be randomly presented.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The data from the Flanker and Lexical tasks will be collected through Mouse Tracker and the questionnaire answers will be computed in an excel file. The only exclusion criteria is if the participant has any speech, hearing, and/or vision impairment.
Recruitment will take place at Maxwell Elementary School, in Lexington Kentucky. All students whose ages range from 8 to 10 years old will be recruited through the teachers in the school. Teachers will give the parents consent forms so the children can participate. We will be collecting data in the school throughout the month of March.

q14.value: Ideally, we would like to have 30 students per grade level, but if that is not possible (e.g., if not enough parents sign the consent form) we would like to have at least 30 children to perform the analyses across all grade levels.

q15.value: Once we have 30 participants from each grade level (or at the end of March) we will stop collecting data.

question.value:
Condition:
In the Flanker task: Congruent/Incongruent/Control
In the Lexical Decision task: NoRules/SpanishPhonology/EnglishPhonology

In the Flanker task and in the Lexical Decision task we will measure:
- Number of errors 
- Reaction Times
- Mouse Trajectories (x-coordinates over time)

The Flanker Effect is the Incongruent minus the Congruent condition
The English Homophone Effect is the English minus the NoRules
The Spanish Homophone Effect is the Spanish minus the NoRules

To test each hypothesis we will perform mixed models using lme4 in R in order to include the random effects of participants and items. 

1A - The Flanker effect (the difference between the congruent and the incongruent conditions in the flanker task) will correlate with the English homophone effect (the difference between the English homophone non-word bloo and the no-rules non-word uebl). 
1B - The Flanker effect (the difference between the congruent and the incongruent conditions in the flanker task) will correlate with the Spanish homophone effect (the difference between the Spanish homophone non-word blu and the no-rules non-word uebl).

registration_responses.q1: The Relationship Between Cognitive and Linguistic Abilities in Bilingual Children
registration_responses.q2: Ines Elena Martin, Sara Incera, Paz Suarez-Coalla
registration_responses.q3: The goal of the present investigation is to determine how bilingualism influences reading. To date few studies have addressed this question despite the millions of children who are learning to read in bilingual environments. The grain size accommodation hypothesis (Lallier & Carreiras, 2018) proposes that cross-linguistic variations (the differences between languages) and cross-linguistic transfer (the influence from one language to another) affect bilingual reading strategies as well as cognitive function. Sparks, Ganschow, and Pohlman (1989) proposed the linguistic coding differences hypothesis to further explain the relationship between native and second-language reading difficulties. These authors suggest that children who have difficulty reading in their native language will also show difficulties reading in their second language. The explanation behind this reasoning is that the same skill deficits will be present because both native and second language reading depend on the same set of linguistic skills (Li, Tao, Joshi, & Xu, 2018; Sparks, Ganschow, & Pohlman, 1989). In the present study we will examine the extent to which reading performance is determine by resistance to distractor interference (as measured in the Flanker task) and practice reading (as measured through a self-report questionnaire of number of hours reading in each language). Our study focuses on the relationship between cognitive and linguistic abilities. Our population are 8 to 10 years-old students that are currently attending a Spanish immersion school in the USA. Students will be presented with two tasks: a Flanker task and a Lexical decision task.
registration_responses.q4:
(1) Students’ performance in the cognitive task (Flanker) will predict students’ performance in the linguistic task (Lexical Decision). 
1A - If cognitive ability (i.e., resistance to distractor interference) is related to phonological interference in the first language of a bilingual, the Flanker effect (the difference between the congruent and the incongruent conditions in the flanker task) will correlate with the English homophone effect (the difference between the English homophone non-word bloo and the no-rules non-word uebl). 
1B - If cognitive ability (i.e., resistance to distractor interference) is related phonological interference in the second language of a bilingual, the Flanker effect (the difference between the congruent and the incongruent conditions in the flanker task) will correlate with the Spanish homophone effect (the difference between the Spanish homophone non-word blu and the no-rules non-word uebl). 

(2) Students’ educational experiences (e.g., self-reported amount of reading) will predict students’ performance in the linguistic task.
- Number of hours reading will correlate with overall performance across conditions in the lexical decision task.

(3) Within the linguistic task, students’ performance in the English pseudohomophones will predict students’ performance in the Spanish pseudohomophones.
- If there is a mechanism that controls phonological interference across languages, the English homophone effect (the difference between the English homophone non-word bloo and the no-rules non-word uebl) will correlate with the Spanish homophone effect (the difference between the Spanish homophone non-word blu and the no-rules non-word uebl).

registration_responses.q8.question: Participants in the present investigation will (1) provide consent, (2) complete tasks in the computer, and (3) respond to a series of questions about their linguistic background. The tasks that participants will complete in the computer will be run using the MouseTracker software, a program that records participants’ computer mouse movements. Participants will first complete the Flanker task (a task that measures resistance to distractor interference) where participants need to ignore the surrounding arrows and click on the direction of the arrow in the center. Second participants will complete a lexical decision task, a reading task where participants need to decide whether a particular string of letters is a word or not. Regarding the questionnaire at the end, all children will be asked the questions orally.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The data from the Flanker and Lexical tasks will be collected through Mouse Tracker and the questionnaire answers will be computed in an excel file. The only exclusion criteria is if the participant has any speech, hearing, and/or vision impairment.
Recruitment will take place at Maxwell Elementary School, in Lexington Kentucky. All students whose ages range from 8 to 10 years old will be recruited through the teachers in the school. Teachers will give the parents consent forms so the children can participate. We will be collecting data in the school throughout the month of March.

q1.value: Meaningful moments in the everyday language environments of English- and Spanish-speaking families from diverse SES backgrounds - REVISION 1

q2.value: Janet Y Bang, Mónica Munévar, Virginia A. Marchman, Anne Fernald

q3.value:
This pre-registration is an amendment of a prior pre-registration (https://osf.io/3tk86) because we recovered data from 4 families that we thought were lost in our English-speaking group, thus we also included 4 more families in our Spanish-speaking group for a total of 45 families in each group (instead of 41). Additionally, we have included the activity of 'overheard speech' (periods of talk not directed to the target child) as a comparison for all relevant analyses. We have neither extracted nor analyzed data regarding overheard speech at the time of this pre-registration. We have also amended the English outcome measure from the CELF-4 to the CELF-5, as well as the age range to 9 - 11 years old (from 8 - 10 years old).

Description
Numerous studies have established links between how caregivers verbally engage with their children and children’s language outcomes. In an effort to encourage interactions that can better support children’s language outcomes, public awareness programs and interventions have begun to promote ways to enrich caregiver-child interactions. One approach is from the framework of target caregivers, by encouraging them to talk more with their children throughout the day (e.g., Suskind et al., 2016), while another approach is to focus on stimulating activities that can support children’s early language and literacy skills (e.g., Reach out and Read). Given the links between low-socioeconomic status (SES), caregiver input, and children’s developmental outcomes (Hart & Risley, 1995; Walker et al. 1994, Hoff, 2003), both approaches have been targeted to families living in low-SES backgrounds. However, effects of such interventions have been found to be small to moderate for children’s outcomes, suggesting that it is still unclear what aspects of children’s language environments can be influenced to support their learning. In this work we investigate caregivers’ verbal engagement with their children, sampled from their densest hour of day-to-day, naturalistic, and spontaneous interactions. This study is a secondary analysis of previously collected data in the Fernald lab. Prior analyses have been run using approximations of the language environment (i.e., using automated estimations from LENA), but never before with transcriptions confirmed for child-directed speech. 

Our goal with this work is to tease apart the extent to which the language learning environment is linked to intra-individual stability within caregivers’ themselves, or whether different activities can change the language learning environment. We also examine how caregivers’ verbal engagement within and across activities is linked to children’s later outcomes. Activities consist of one-on-one child-centered activities of book reading, play, food-related activities, routines, and unstructured conversation, as well as adult-centered activities (e.g., periods of divided adult engagement such as doing the laundry but providing child-directed speech), and periods of overheard speech. We include both English- and Spanish-speaking families from diverse SES backgrounds, providing a more comprehensive picture of caregiver-child interactions.

q4.value:
Given the many differences between English- and Spanish-speaking families, in addition to SES and language, we choose to examine the following questions within English-speaking and Spanish-speaking families rather than including them in one model. 

1)	Do different features of dense caregiver verbal engagement vary across different activities during caregiver-child interactions?
a.	Based on prior work (e.g., Dunn et al., 1977; Hoff-Ginsberg, 1991; Soderstrom & Wittebolle, 2013; Sosa, 2016), for verbal engagement variables of quantity (word tokens) and quality (word types, MLU) we predict that verbal engagement during book reading will be higher than in all other activities (i.e., 6 levels: book reading, play, food, routines, unstructured conversation, adult-centered activities). We do not have predictions for differences between other activities. However, we will examine all comparisons using post-hoc comparisons.
b.	Based on some prior work (Hoff-Ginsberg, 1991; Sosa, 2016), for variables of interaction (responses to child utterances, and imitations/expansions, and turns), we predict few differences between book reading and other activities. We do not have predictions for differences between other activities. However, we will examine all comparisons using post-hoc comparisons.

2)	Do different features of dense caregiver verbal engagement during one activity relate to dense verbal engagement in other activities?
a.	If features of caregiver verbal engagement are related to intra-individual stability within caregivers’ themselves, we expect positive correlations of verbal engagement between activities.
b.	If activities can change certain features of caregiver verbal engagement, we expect few positive correlations of caregiver verbal engagement between activities.

3)	Does the relation between SES and different features of dense caregiver verbal engagement vary across different activities?
a.	If specific activities can change the relation between caregiver verbal engagement and SES (e.g., book reading), we would expect to see relations between SES and caregiver verbal engagement during some activities and not others.
b.	If specific activities do not change the relation between caregiver verbal engagement and SES, we do not expect to see different relations between SES and caregiver verbal engagement across activities.

4)	Do dense features of caregiver verbal engagement at 24-months link to children’s concurrent and later language outcomes? In English-speaking families, we evaluate later outcomes when children are 8-10 years old. In Spanish-speaking families we evaluate later outcomes when children are 4.5 years old.
a.	If caregiver verbal engagement during all activities relates to children’s language outcomes, we predict positive relations with children’s outcomes during all activities. 
b.	If caregiver verbal engagement during certain activities (e.g., book reading) relates to children’s language outcomes, we predict positive relations with children’s outcomes during certain activities and not others.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Coders did not have any values for independent or dependent variables available at the time of coding (i.e., families’ Hollingshead score or maternal education, child outcome variables).

question.value:
Caregiver input variables are repeated measures, with 6, 10-minute recordings per family, thus each family provides 6 observations for each input feature. 

We do not plan to correct for multiple comparisons so that we can preserve maximum power to detect associations.

q9.value: This is an observational study with no randomization.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value:
Prior analysis of data: 
Analyses of caregiver verbal engagement using transcriptions were never analyzed at the time of this pre-registration. Preliminary analyses of the language environment were conducted using estimations of the LENA automated values of adult word count (AWC) and conversational turns (CTC) with all 45 English-speaking and 45 Spanish-speaking families. These estimations were calculated as follows: 1) LENA estimates were provided for the full 10-minute segment, 2) The duration of the time spent during each interaction within the 10-minute segment (e.g., 5 minutes of book reading and 2 minutes of play) were multiplied by the LENA estimates (e.g., 5/10 minutes during book reading x 1000 AWC = 500 words during book reading and 2/10 minutes during play x 1000 AWC = 200 words during play).

These estimates are limited because they do not consider how the language provided during the interactions are linked to the specific activities during the interaction; therefore, these estimates may under- or over-estimate the input during different activities. Moreover, LENA estimates of AWC or CTC provide no information regarding qualitative information of the language used (e.g., different types, sentence complexity), or of specific ways that caregivers respond to children’s language (e.g., imitations, expansions). 

However, the covariates included for the proposed analyses are based on the aforementioned analyses with this dataset. These covariates are listed below in the results section.

English-speaking families
Nineteen families in the current sample were used in the sample of 28 families in Fernald, Marchman, & Weisleder (2013), which explored links between SES and children’s language outcomes at 18 and 24 months. The present dataset includes 45 families, which includes an additional 22 families whose data were collected after publication. Therefore, we were aware of relations between SES and children’s concurrent language outcomes at 24 months that could occur with our sample of 45 families, specifically with outcomes of the CDI and Looking-While-Listening accuracy and response time variables. Fernald et al., 2013 did not examine caregiver verbal engagement.

Spanish-speaking families
The 45 families are a subset of families who are participating in a larger longitudinal study. These 45 families were included to ensure that they represented the full possible range of SES and met exclusion criteria below. We first included all families with scores of 30 or more on the Hollingshead Index (n = 16), then we sampled families who had scores below 30 (n = 29).

question.value:
English
Data collection is detailed in Fernald et al., 2013. 

Spanish
Spanish-speaking families were recruited through birth records and community centers, and are part of a larger longitudinal study.

q13.value:
English
Our sample includes 45 families, of which 19 are a subset of the 49 available families that had caregiver input data from Site 2 of Fernald et al. 2013. Eight families were excluded prior to coding for the reasons noted below. For each family, we selected 6 non-contiguous, 10-minute audio segments from their day-long LENA recording, which represented each family’s densest hour of child-directed speech. 

•	Twins (2)
•	Less than 4 hours of uncleaned recordings (2)
•	More than 8 hours recorded at daycare (1)
•	LENA worn incorrectly (on the back of the child) or not on the child (3)

Spanish
See explanation above for how 45 Spanish-speaking families were sampled.

q14.value:
Data from our English-speaking families were already collected at the time of study design and analysis, thus we decided to use all available data that fit our inclusion criteria. Power analyses were calculated to estimate the proposed links between caregiver input and children’s later outcomes; we used Pearson’s r correlations using the pwr package in R (Champely, 2018). 

For an estimate of relations between caregiver verbal engagement and children’s language outcomes, we used the following relations from previous studies: 
•	Caregiver talk at 19 months measured by LENA AWC of confirmed child-directed speech and children’s 24-month vocabulary (Weisleder & Fernald, 2013); r = .57, n = 29, p < .01. With our sample size of 41, the power to detect a correlation of .57 is .98. This approximation is the most similar to our analyses because our measures will also be confirmed as child-directed speech.
•	Caregiver talk at 18-24 months measured by LENA AWC and CTC (no confirmation of child-directed speech) and children’s PPVT scores at 6 – 16 years of age (Gilkerson et al., 2018).
      - AWC and PPVT r = .33, n = 44, p = .03; with our sample size of 41, the power to detect a correlation of .33 is .57.
      - CTC and PPVT r = .43, n = 44, p < .01; with our sample size of 41, the power to detect a correlation of .43 is .82.

q15.value:
For English-speaking families, all possible children available were included in our analyses. Though our power estimates suggest that we did not need to include all children, our method differed from Weisleder & Fernald, 2013. Therefore, including all children assured that we were able to maximize power in this sample.

For Spanish-speaking families, see rationale above for those that were included. Though additional families could be included, we did not choose to include more families due to the intensity of coding and transcription.

question.value:
Caregivers will be defined as any adult who provides child-directed speech to target children (siblings 13 or older are considered adults), collapsing across all caregivers per 10-minute segment. 

Measures of activity type
6 categorical levels: book reading, play, food-related, routine, unstructured conversation, adult-centered activities, and overheard speech.

Measures of caregiver verbal engagement (6 total)
These measures are calculated using CLAN (MacWhinney, 2012). This includes all child-directed speech, including recited language (e.g., reading from book text, singing songs). After transcription is complete, we will create a list of communicators to exclude from analyses of quantity and quality measures (e.g., uh, hmm). 
•	Quantity:
        -  Word tokens/minute
•	Quality
        - Word types/minute (calculated using lemmas, which are automated using the MOR program in CLAN). 
        - MLU (this value is already a rate)
•	Interaction (these do not exclude second language)
        - Proportion of caregiver responses to child (out of child’s utterances)
        - Proportion of imitations/expansion (out of child’s utterances)
        - Turns/minute (This is calculated from the transcription and is the number of back and forth turns between a caregiver and a child. This is different from the LENA CTC variable which estimates the number of turns based on the timing of a speaker’s response. While our turns measure does not account for timing, we calculate this during interactions of CDS, thus we can be more assured that these turns are between the caregiver and child).

Child outcome variables
Concurrent
•	CDI words produced at 24 months
•	Looking-While-Listening Accuracy at 24 months
•	Looking-While-Listening RT at 24 months

Later outcomes
•	Spanish: A composite of the CELF-4 Expressive Language and TVIP (Spanish receptive vocabulary size) 
•	English: CELF-5 Core Langauge

Covariates (these covariates were determined through analyses with LENA estimates noted above)
•	Child talkativeness measured by child word tokens. This measure excludes any elicited imitations (e.g., caregivers asks child to repeat “apple” and child says “apple”).
•	SES measured by the Hollingshead Index
•	Children’s earlier language measured by the MacArthur-Bates Child Development Inventories
•	*Spanish only: percent of caregiver Spanish exposure at 4.5 years old

1)	Do different features of dense caregiver verbal engagement vary across different 
activities during caregiver-child interactions?
a.	Analyses will be conducted using linear mixed models for each verbal engagement measure, for a total of 6 models in each group. Post hoc tests will examine differences between all activities if there is a significant main effect of activity type.
b.	Random intercepts: We will include random intercepts of participant and recording segment (1-6). If the model does not converge, we will remove the random intercept of recording segment before participant.
c.	Covariates: child word tokens

2)	Do different features of dense caregiver verbal engagement during one activity relate to dense verbal engagement in other activities? 
a.	We will conduct correlations between verbal engagement measures to assess whether all measures will be examined separately, excluded, or turned into one or more composite variables.
b.	Analyses will be conducted using Pearson’s r. For each family, we will average across the verbal engagement measure within each activity. 

3)	Does the relation between SES and different verbal engagement features vary across different activities?
a.	Analyses will be conducted using linear mixed models. The number of models will be determined based on correlations of verbal engagement measures above. Activities will be collapsed to increase our power to detect interactions with SES. We will group activities into the following: 1) book reading 2) other child-centered activities, 3) adult-centered activities, and 4) ohs. Post hoc tests will be conducted if there is a significant interaction between SES and caregiver verbal engagement.
b.	Random intercepts: We will include random intercepts of participant and recording segment (1-6). If the model does not converge, we will remove the random intercept of recording segment before participant.
c.	Covariates: child total word tokens 

4)	Do dense features of caregiver verbal engagement at 24-months link to children’s concurrent and later outcomes? In English-speaking families, we evaluate later outcomes when children are 8-10 years old. In Spanish-speaking families we evaluate later outcomes when children are 4.5 years old. As above, the number of verbal engagement measures examined will be based on correlations above. Activities will be collapsed into the same 4 categories used above in question (2). 
a.	Analyses will be conducted using multiple linear regression, using list-wise deletion for children who do not have book reading. 
b.	Covariates: child talkativeness, children’s earlier language abilities (CDI), SES, and for 
Spanish-speaking families we will also include Spanish language exposure.

q20.value: The categorical variable of context will be dummy coded. All covariates and continuous predictors will be mean centered to reduce collinearity.

q21.value: Inferences will be made from two-tailed tests of p-values < .05.

q22.value: All data to be excluded have been removed prior to analyses (see exclusion criteria above).

q23.value:
When data are missing for children’s language outcomes, those children will be excluded from analysis. 

When data are missing for caregiver verbal engagement measures, we will not impute, nor do we exclude these families because this reflected a true instance of ‘missing’ for that measure. For example, it is possible that for one family that there were never instances of book reading in their densest hour. Including a value of ‘0’ would bring down the average score, thus providing a poor prediction of relations for those families that do engage in book reading.

q24.value:
Context levels. We will explore the following combination of activity types: 
-	3 levels: book reading vs. all other activities vs. overheard speech
-	2 levels: combining across all other activities vs. overheard speech

Relations between caregiver verbal engagement and child outcomes. For question (4), we will explore the relation between caregiver input and other child outcomes (e.g., executive function, literacy, math)

Book reading language. We will explore the role of recited (reading from the text) vs. spontaneous speech (extra-textual talk).

Prior analysis of data: 
Analyses of caregiver verbal engagement using transcriptions were never analyzed at the time of this pre-registration. Preliminary analyses of the language environment were conducted using estimations of the LENA automated values of adult word count (AWC) and conversational turns (CTC) with all 45 English-speaking and 45 Spanish-speaking families. These estimations were calculated as follows: 1) LENA estimates were provided for the full 10-minute segment, 2) The duration of the time spent during each interaction within the 10-minute segment (e.g., 5 minutes of book reading and 2 minutes of play) were multiplied by the LENA estimates (e.g., 5/10 minutes during book reading x 1000 AWC = 500 words during book reading and 2/10 minutes during play x 1000 AWC = 200 words during play).

These estimates are limited because they do not consider how the language provided during the interactions are linked to the specific activities during the interaction; therefore, these estimates may under- or over-estimate the input during different activities. Moreover, LENA estimates of AWC or CTC provide no information regarding qualitative information of the language used (e.g., different types, sentence complexity), or of specific ways that caregivers respond to children’s language (e.g., imitations, expansions). 

However, the covariates included for the proposed analyses are based on the aforementioned analyses with this dataset. These covariates are listed below in the results section.

English-speaking families
Nineteen families in the current sample were used in the sample of 28 families in Fernald, Marchman, & Weisleder (2013), which explored links between SES and children’s language outcomes at 18 and 24 months. The present dataset includes 45 families, which includes an additional 22 families whose data were collected after publication. Therefore, we were aware of relations between SES and children’s concurrent language outcomes at 24 months that could occur with our sample of 45 families, specifically with outcomes of the CDI and Looking-While-Listening accuracy and response time variables. Fernald et al., 2013 did not examine caregiver verbal engagement.

Spanish-speaking families
The 45 families are a subset of families who are participating in a larger longitudinal study. These 45 families were included to ensure that they represented the full possible range of SES and met exclusion criteria below. We first included all families with scores of 30 or more on the Hollingshead Index (n = 16), then we sampled families who had scores below 30 (n = 29).
registration_responses.q13:
English
Our sample includes 45 families, of which 19 are a subset of the 49 available families that had caregiver input data from Site 2 of Fernald et al. 2013. Eight families were excluded prior to coding for the reasons noted below. For each family, we selected 6 non-contiguous, 10-minute audio segments from their day-long LENA recording, which represented each family’s densest hour of child-directed speech. 

•	Twins (2)
•	Less than 4 hours of uncleaned recordings (2)
•	More than 8 hours recorded at daycare (1)
•	LENA worn incorrectly (on the back of the child) or not on the child (3)

Spanish
See explanation above for how 45 Spanish-speaking families were sampled.
registration_responses.q14:
Data from our English-speaking families were already collected at the time of study design and analysis, thus we decided to use all available data that fit our inclusion criteria. Power analyses were calculated to estimate the proposed links between caregiver input and children’s later outcomes; we used Pearson’s r correlations using the pwr package in R (Champely, 2018). 

For an estimate of relations between caregiver verbal engagement and children’s language outcomes, we used the following relations from previous studies: 
•	Caregiver talk at 19 months measured by LENA AWC of confirmed child-directed speech and children’s 24-month vocabulary (Weisleder & Fernald, 2013); r = .57, n = 29, p < .01. With our sample size of 41, the power to detect a correlation of .57 is .98. This approximation is the most similar to our analyses because our measures will also be confirmed as child-directed speech.
•	Caregiver talk at 18-24 months measured by LENA AWC and CTC (no confirmation of child-directed speech) and children’s PPVT scores at 6 – 16 years of age (Gilkerson et al., 2018).
      - AWC and PPVT r = .33, n = 44, p = .03; with our sample size of 41, the power to detect a correlation of .33 is .57.
      - CTC and PPVT r = .43, n = 44, p < .01; with our sample size of 41, the power to detect a correlation of .43 is .82.
registration_responses.q15:
For English-speaking families, all possible children available were included in our analyses. Though our power estimates suggest that we did not need to include all children, our method differed from Weisleder & Fernald, 2013. Therefore, including all children assured that we were able to maximize power in this sample.

For Spanish-speaking families, see rationale above for those that were included. Though additional families could be included, we did not choose to include more families due to the intensity of coding and transcription.
registration_responses.q20: The categorical variable of context will be dummy coded. All covariates and continuous predictors will be mean centered to reduce collinearity.
registration_responses.q21: Inferences will be made from two-tailed tests of p-values < .05.
registration_responses.q22: All data to be excluded have been removed prior to analyses (see exclusion criteria above).
registration_responses.q23:
When data are missing for children’s language outcomes, those children will be excluded from analysis. 

When data are missing for caregiver verbal engagement measures, we will not impute, nor do we exclude these families because this reflected a true instance of ‘missing’ for that measure. For example, it is possible that for one family that there were never instances of book reading in their densest hour. Including a value of ‘0’ would bring down the average score, thus providing a poor prediction of relations for those families that do engage in book reading.
registration_responses.q24:
Context levels. We will explore the following combination of activity types: 
-	3 levels: book reading vs. all other activities vs. overheard speech
-	2 levels: combining across all other activities vs. overheard speech

Relations between caregiver verbal engagement and child outcomes. For question (4), we will explore the relation between caregiver input and other child outcomes (e.g., executive function, literacy, math)

Book reading language. We will explore the role of recited (reading from the text) vs. spontaneous speech (extra-textual talk).
registration_responses.q8.question:
Caregiver input variables are repeated measures, with 6, 10-minute recordings per family, thus each family provides 6 observations for each input feature. 

We do not plan to correct for multiple comparisons so that we can preserve maximum power to detect associations.
registration_responses.q12.question:
English
Data collection is detailed in Fernald et al., 2013. 

Spanish
Spanish-speaking families were recruited through birth records and community centers, and are part of a larger longitudinal study.
registration_responses.q16.question: This is not applicable.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Caregivers will be defined as any adult who provides child-directed speech to target children (siblings 13 or older are considered adults), collapsing across all caregivers per 10-minute segment. 

Measures of activity type
6 categorical levels: book reading, play, food-related, routine, unstructured conversation, adult-centered activities, and overheard speech.

Measures of caregiver verbal engagement (6 total)
These measures are calculated using CLAN (MacWhinney, 2012). This includes all child-directed speech, including recited language (e.g., reading from book text, singing songs). After transcription is complete, we will create a list of communicators to exclude from analyses of quantity and quality measures (e.g., uh, hmm). 
•	Quantity:
        -  Word tokens/minute
•	Quality
        - Word types/minute (calculated using lemmas, which are automated using the MOR program in CLAN). 
        - MLU (this value is already a rate)
•	Interaction (these do not exclude second language)
        - Proportion of caregiver responses to child (out of child’s utterances)
        - Proportion of imitations/expansion (out of child’s utterances)
        - Turns/minute (This is calculated from the transcription and is the number of back and forth turns between a caregiver and a child. This is different from the LENA CTC variable which estimates the number of turns based on the timing of a speaker’s response. While our turns measure does not account for timing, we calculate this during interactions of CDS, thus we can be more assured that these turns are between the caregiver and child).

Child outcome variables
Concurrent
•	CDI words produced at 24 months
•	Looking-While-Listening Accuracy at 24 months
•	Looking-While-Listening RT at 24 months

Later outcomes
•	Spanish: A composite of the CELF-4 Expressive Language and TVIP (Spanish receptive vocabulary size) 
•	English: CELF-5 Core Langauge

Covariates (these covariates were determined through analyses with LENA estimates noted above)
•	Child talkativeness measured by child word tokens. This measure excludes any elicited imitations (e.g., caregivers asks child to repeat “apple” and child says “apple”).
•	SES measured by the Hollingshead Index
•	Children’s earlier language measured by the MacArthur-Bates Child Development Inventories
•	*Spanish only: percent of caregiver Spanish exposure at 4.5 years old
registration_responses.q19.question:
1)	Do different features of dense caregiver verbal engagement vary across different 
activities during caregiver-child interactions?
a.	Analyses will be conducted using linear mixed models for each verbal engagement measure, for a total of 6 models in each group. Post hoc tests will examine differences between all activities if there is a significant main effect of activity type.
b.	Random intercepts: We will include random intercepts of participant and recording segment (1-6). If the model does not converge, we will remove the random intercept of recording segment before participant.
c.	Covariates: child word tokens

2)	Do different features of dense caregiver verbal engagement during one activity relate to dense verbal engagement in other activities? 
a.	We will conduct correlations between verbal engagement measures to assess whether all measures will be examined separately, excluded, or turned into one or more composite variables.
b.	Analyses will be conducted using Pearson’s r. For each family, we will average across the verbal engagement measure within each activity. 

3)	Does the relation between SES and different verbal engagement features vary across different activities?
a.	Analyses will be conducted using linear mixed models. The number of models will be determined based on correlations of verbal engagement measures above. Activities will be collapsed to increase our power to detect interactions with SES. We will group activities into the following: 1) book reading 2) other child-centered activities, 3) adult-centered activities, and 4) ohs. Post hoc tests will be conducted if there is a significant interaction between SES and caregiver verbal engagement.
b.	Random intercepts: We will include random intercepts of participant and recording segment (1-6). If the model does not converge, we will remove the random intercept of recording segment before participant.
c.	Covariates: child total word tokens 

4)	Do dense features of caregiver verbal engagement at 24-months link to children’s concurrent and later outcomes? In English-speaking families, we evaluate later outcomes when children are 8-10 years old. In Spanish-speaking families we evaluate later outcomes when children are 4.5 years old. As above, the number of verbal engagement measures examined will be based on correlations above. Activities will be collapsed into the same 4 categories used above in question (2). 
a.	Analyses will be conducted using multiple linear regression, using list-wise deletion for children who do not have book reading. 
b.	Covariates: child talkativeness, children’s earlier language abilities (CDI), SES, and for 
Spanish-speaking families we will also include Spanish language exposure.

attributes.title: The Spatial Politics of Support for Mass Infrastructure: A Pre-Analysis Plan

q1.value: The Spatial Politics of Support for Mass Infrastructure: A Pre-Analysis Plan

q5.value: The Lincoln Institute for Land Policy provided the funding for this project; Consultoría Nacional de Colombia (CNC) implemented the survey. I thank Doug von Kohorn for programming assistance, and Natalia Duarte for translation and research assistance.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This project examines public support for mass infrastructure projects, such as roads and metros, using a new survey technique designed to elicit the intensity of citizens’ preferences called Quadratic Voting. It is interested in how income, property ownership, and distance from a project influences the relative priority that citizens place on infrastructure projects. It also examines how different forms of project financing change popular support and engagement with infrastructure projects using a survey experiment, and the relative importance of taxes in citizens' willingness to reward politicians for infrastructure investments using a conjoint experiment. It addresses these questions in the context of Bogotá, Colombia, where the city government is contemplating building a new metro project and still deciding on the right model to finance such a large scale investment. Combined, this project sheds new light on why infrastructure spending, especially on urban transit projects, remains so limited in developing countries.

q16.value: This project tests two major groups of hypotheses about the class determinants of infrastructure support and the ways in which project financing alters support. First, much of the literature on comparative politics assumes that the poor prefer direct redistributive transfers to the diffuse and often delayed gains from infrastructure investments. But this assumption is rarely examined, and existing survey instruments, usually asking respondents a series of questions about their support for a given issue, provide limited leverage to understand public priorities. This project therefore uses a new survey technique called Quadratic Voting (QV) that provides respondents a budget to spend across a group of survey questions and therefore leads them to consider both the intensity and direction of their preferences. Using this technique, I test my hypothesis that low-income groups indeed prioritize redistributive spending, but they also care about urban transit projects that affect their everyday quality of life. I also examine how the distance from a project and commuting patterns impact stated priorities. The second set of hypotheses relate to how taxation affects support for infrastructure projects. Mass transit projects, in particular, tend to be enormously expensive, and generate windfall gains for some nearby property owners and regular transit users, concentrated losses among those who have their land seized, and diffuse benefits for most others. A major question is how to distribute these uneven costs in city space. My hypotheses relate to how financial instruments can affect the distribution of support across property owners and renters, and those who live nearby and distant from mass transit projects. In particular, I expect that value-capture mechanisms that levy special fees on nearby property owners have the potential to create a more even distribution of support for major infrastructure projects. While they reduce support among those property owners who expect to see windfall gains, they boost support in the rest of the city. Bogotá has a long history of using value-capture mechanisms to fund infrastructure and thus represents an ideal case to test these hypotheses.

q17.value: The first set of hypotheses will be tested by examining the coefficient on income in linear regressions using the votes placed on infrastructure and redistributive issues as dependent variables. I will also analyze whether distance from a project, property ownership, and commute time are associated with placing greater weight on infrastructure projects. The second set of hypotheses will be tested through a survey experiment that will provide different information about how a metro project will be funded to respondents. I will analyze how different funding schemes changes support for the project (evaluated through QV, a Likert question, and interest in the project) by class, property ownership status, and distance from the metro project.

attributes.title: The Impact of Mindfulness-Based Resilience Training on Stress-Related Biological, Behavioral, and Health-Related Outcomes in Law Enforcement Officers
attributes.description: The Impact of Mindfulness-Based Resilience Training on Pain-Related Dysfunctions in Law Enforcement Officers

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The Impact of Mindfulness-Based Resilience Training on Pain-Related Dysfunctions in Law Enforcement Officers

other.value:
We have already collected all data and carried out quality control for self-report data, but have not yet begun analyses related to the hypotheses described above.

Note that 6 items of FFMQ-SF for Cohort 1 were missing at baseline due to an error in entering questions into our online survey. We will impute missing data using the mean score of items collected for each subscale. For additional details on this survey, see (https://osf.io/xeb7a).

Exploratory analyses:
1. We will test whether individual differences (e.g., Days and minutes of formal practice during the 8-week intervention, gender, cohort, work shift, job category, years of experience) will influence the outcome variables. If so, they will be constrained as covariates in mediation models. For detailed description of these covariates, see (https://osf.io/mqnga). 

2. We will also test whether the mMBRT intervention effect can be maintained at T3. As for the mediation effect for T3, we assume that mMBRT group will reduce change scores (T3-T1) in pain-related dysfunctions through increasing change scores (T3-T1) in mindfulness and/or resilience compared with waitlist control condition. Constrained models will also be tested.

sample.value: We planned to collect data from 120 participants at each of 3 assessments (with an estimated 10% attrition by T3). This number was determined as part of the larger study design for the overarching clinical trial. Our actual enrollment total was 115 participants at T1, 109 participants at T2, and 104 participants at T3.

analyses.value:
The “lmer” and “lavaan” packages in R will be used for main analyses.

To test group differences on change scores (T2-T1) of all measures (i.e., pain intensity, pain interference, depression, anxiety, perceived stress, mindfulness, resilience), mixed models will be used. Participants will be included as a random effect nested within “Class”, which corresponds to each of the 4 different mindfulness classes during the study (with a 5th class corresponding to waitlist participants). For the FFMQ-SF, both the total score and each subscale will be analyzed. As an example, the syntax for the pain intensity model will be:
lmer(Pain intensity~ Group*Time + (1 | Class/Subject)

To test H2, structural equation modeling will be used to assess mindfulness and resilience (T2-T1 change scores) as potential mediators in associations between intervention and T2-T1 change scores of pain-related dysfunction variables (i.e., pain intensity, pain interference, depression, anxiety, perceived stress). Then, only those pain-related dysfunction variables that have significant correlations with mindfulness (both total scores of FFMQ-SF and each subscale score), resilience, and the dummy group variable will be included in the mediation model. Pain-related dysfunction variables as outcome measures will be 
1) tested separately in the mediation model: 
pain intensity changes ~intervention + mindfulness changes
pain intensity changes ~intervention + resilience changes

2) treated as a latent variable:
Pain-related dysfunction changes~intervention+mindfulness changes
Pain-related dysfunction changes~intervention+resilience changes
Pain-related dysfunction changes =~ pain intensity changes + pain interference changes + depression changes + anxiety changes + perceived stress changes

The overarching hypothesis is that mMBRT will reduce pain-related dysfunction through increasing scores in mindfulness and/or resilience compared with the waitlist control condition. We will also modify hypothesized models listed above according to bivariate correlation matrix.

outliers.value: For self-report measures, outliers will be defined as observations greater than 3 SDs from the mean and they will be excluded.

dependent.value:
1. Pain intensity will be assessed via PROMIS–43 Profile v2.0. There is one single item asking “How would you rate your pain on average in the past 7 days?”. Pain intensity scores will be ranged from 0 (no pain) to 10 (worst imaginable pain).
2. Pain interference will be assessed through a 6-item subscale of PROMIS. It assesses pain interference in the past 7 days. Higher total scores indicate more severe pain interference (1 = not at all, 5 = very much), with a possible range of 6-30.
3. Depression will be assessed via a 6-item subscale of PROMIS. It assesses depressive emotions in the past 7 days. Higher total scores indicate more depressive symptoms (1 = never, 5 = always), with a possible range of 6-30.
4. Anxiety will be assessed via a 6-item subscale of PROMIS. It assesses anxious emotions in the past 7 days. Higher total scores indicate more anxiety (1 = never, 5 = always), with a possible range of 6-30.
5. Perceived stress will be assessed by the 10-item Perceived Stress Scale (PSS; Cohen, 1988). Higher total scores indicate more perceived stress (0 = never, 4 = very often) in the last month, while scores of four items need to be reversed. 
6. Trait mindfulness will be assessed by Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire-Short Form (FFMQ-SF; Bohlmeijer, Ten Klooster, Fledderus, Veehof, & Baer, 2011). FFMQ-SF is a 24-item scale assessing different facets of trait mindfulness including observing (4 items), describing (5 items), acting with awareness (5 items), non-judging of (5 items) and non-reactivity to inner experiences (5 items). Both total score of each facet and a sum of all facets will be used for analyses. Higher total scores indicate more capacity in that mindfulness skill (1 = never or very rarely true, 5 = very often or always true). **See note about this measure in "Other" section below**
7. Resilience will be assessed by Brief Resilience Scale (BRS; Smith et al., 2008). The 6-item BRS assesses general capacity to bounce back from adversities. There are three reverse scored items. A higher total score indicates more resilience for general situation (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), with a possible range of 6-30.

conditions.value: A total of 120 police officers will be recruited from Dane County law enforcement agencies and randomly assigned to two conditions: (1) the MBRT group will receive the 8-week Mindfulness Based Resilience Training and (2) A waitlist control group will receive no intervention until after all study procedures. For additional details on these groups and randomization, see (https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT03488875).

hypothesis.value:
H1. mMBRT (Madison-Mindfulness Based Resilience Training) will decrease self-reported pain (i.e., pain severity, pain interference) and emotional distress (i.e., depression, anxiety, perceived stress), and increase self-reported general resilience and mindfulness compared with the control group.
H2. Changes of mindfulness and resilience will mediate the association between the intervention (mMBRT vs control) and changes of pain-related outcomes (T2-T1).

study_type_other.value:
Additional variables and hypotheses for the over-arching clinical trial are available at 
1. https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT0348887
2. https://osf.io/wt3y9
3. https://osf.io/mqnga
4. https://osf.io/xeb7a
